row.Body:
All around the world, the age of consent varies from 12 to 18 (or more?).

Because of this, there could be a lot of opinion, and possible inaccuracies, when asking questions about the age of consent.

What will we do with these questions?
row.Title: Will questions revolving around the age of consent be on topic?

row.Body:
Health Stack Exchange has a side banner that indicates that it's for educational purposes only:

Health Stack Exchange is for educational purposes only and is not intended as a substitute for individualized diagnosis and treatment by a qualified healthcare provider.

This contains a link to a Meta question on Health.SE, so we'd likely have to create one here, too.

This generally seems like a Good Thing, since we're likely going to be dealing with the same topics and touching on the same problems Health will. Should we add it here?
row.Title: Should we include the sidebar disclaimer that Health.SE has?

row.Body:
At the current stage, it seems that no one has crossed the minimum reputation to approve edits/ tag-wiki,etc.

In such a case, how will my suggested edits be approved? Do only moderators have the right to allow those edits as valid?

Also, I want to suggest some synonyms for a few tags here. How should I add it, as I don't know abut minimum reputation status!
row.Title: How will my added tag-wiki be approved?

row.Body:
OK, so I assume many of you reading this have seen the "Men Health" section of Yahoo! Answers, which is kind of sharing the same purpose. 90% of the questions there are "Is my size normal" and 99% of the rest are, sorry for the word, crap.

So I will focus here on one critical point for now: how to prevent the possible flood of "Is my size normal?" questions? What should we do with those questions when they come?

Two ways I have in mind:

  1. Keep one, close all the rest as dupe.

  2. Burn them with fire.

More ways and/or opinions are welcome.
row.Title: Ways to prevent this site from becoming like Yahoo! Answers

row.Body:
My question Are there any animals, other than humans, which enjoy voyeurism? was closed on the grounds that it does not directly relate to human sexuality. The exact same question was asked during the Definition phase, and got a positive reception (+15/-3).

I think this question ought to be re-opened. Animal sexual behavior is often used as a baseline when studying normative human sexual behavior. Studies on animal masturbation, homosexuality, sexual dominance, engaging in sexual activity for pleasure (as opposed to strictly for procreation), non-monogamy, etc, are easy to find, and are frequently used as a baseline to better understand human sexual behavior and urges. It seems to me that this type of question ought to be on-topic here, as meaningful, interesting, and relevant to those who study human sexual behavior.

This, of course, is in contrast to other issues of animal sexual behavior which have no relevance to human sexual behavior, such as how rabbits respond to different pheromones in a potential partner, or how long collies are typically in heat.
row.Title: Is "Animal voyeurism" question on-topic?

row.Body:
I can see in the future of the site -- and have already seen a couple questions -- concerning how people feel about sex and sexual acts, wherein the body of the question is "how do I deal with feeling a certain way/how I think?"

Are questions about cognitive/emotional processes on-topic here, or will the site have a more explicit medical/physical focus?

I'm a little conflicted about it, personally, because certain topics like BDSM really do warrant a discussion of how the involved people feel emotionally as well as physically, but in contrast there could be a lot of questions about unanswerable topics, like helping individuals grow more comfortable with X. Those questions might have concrete answers, but I'm not sure if we're the best ones to answer them.

How should we prepare ourselves to handle these questions?
row.Title: Are questions about how people feel on-topic?

row.Body:
We're getting a number of questions about "How do I do X to my Y-gendered partner?"

We seem to be doing a good job of mentioning the gender of our partner, but often overlook our own gender.

Consider this one: How to reach female orgasm

Nothing in the question indicates the gender of the asker. (That may make the question 'too broad', or 'unclear what you're asking', but I think that's a separate issue).

Should we tag questions accordingly? If so, to what degree? It seems to me the goal ought to be to tell, at a glance, the relevant gender(s). "How to give my female partner orgasm" differs widely from whether you yourself are a man or a woman (not to mention a plethora of other things, which may lend weight to a "too broad" classification).

I can imagine various such tagging systems:

male-female, male-male, male-female-female, etc

Or even more specific, to indicate who's acting:

male-to-female, female-to-male, etc

Thoughts?
row.Title: Do we need gender tags?

row.Body:
If this site is going to succeed, it's going to need to be a place where people feel they are getting reliable answers to their questions about sexuality. Using slang works against that goal.

I'm going to pick on an answer to make my point:

Don't just start [off] with her pussy.

As I read that sentence (and several others in that answer that make the same mistake) it seemed less like something an expert in human sexuality might say and more like what I heard on the school yard as a boy. I think this variation makes the same point with a more professional vibe:

Don't just start [off] with her genitalia.

Both versions have the same basic meaning, but I hope you agree the second gives off an aura of authority that the first does not.

Obviously different people have different word-choice preferences. But on this site, it would be best to chose clinical terms whenever possible.
row.Title: Please avoid using slang when possible

row.Body:
I don't know about anyone else, but I don't want my username appearing in search results, with potentially-risque questions or answers from this new "sexuality" exchange site.

There are legitimate reasons to use a single login for all stack exchange websites, but for this site in particular, I'd like to be able to hide my username from my posts.
row.Title: Usernames should be optionally anonymous on this site

row.Body: It seems like the private beta Q&A has a large number of non-native writers. I haven't seen this elsewhere on (English) SE sites. Should we bother to edit every post that has language problems? Or is it customary to just leave those alone?
row.Title: Should we care about very bad English?

row.Body:
How should it be handled?

As an example, if a question is stated: "How can my girlfriend make it more comfortable when giving me blowjobs?"

Then the answers will probably be "She can ..."

  • If another person asks "How can my boyfriend make it more comfortable when giving me blowjobs?" Would that be considered a duplicate?
  • Could the first question be edited in to "my partner" or should those two questions be separate?

I understand there might be a difference in the answers at times due to physiology. But in many questions it does not matter.

Is quite related to: Do we need gender tags?
row.Title: Gender neutrality?

row.Body:
Many sites have a banner on top:







However, when this site graduates, I don't think we should have one. I mean this site is about sexuality, so whatever goes about the banner has to be about the site, which means a big ________ when you visit the site. That instantly means a NSFW warning. Could we just stick to a stackoverflow-like banner?

Also, the image should just be something like this:

We can keep it simple.
row.Title: Should we have a site banner when we become a full site?

row.Body:
I've recently edited a question to change around some sentences and improve small typos. One of the things that I edited was 'Females' to 'Women' as, to me, it's a bit peculiar to speak about women as Female Homo Sapiens, or about men as 'Male humans'.

I would prefer 'Men' over 'Males' and 'Women' over 'Females' generally, in the context of this site.

Should I continue to make edits that include this change, or is my non-native English just acting up here?
row.Title: Male -> Man, Female -> Woman

row.Body:
We currently use tags such as male and female to distinguish between male and female respectively (go figure).

For example, a question about male ejaculation would be tagged {maleejaculation}.

Do we need a separate tag for female-ejaculation? Could we instead do the same as we currently do for male ejaculation - and tag questions as femaleejaculation?

Or alternatively, should we split the ejaculation tag into the existing female-ejaculation and a new male-ejaculation tag - i.e. completely replace the current use of ejaculation?
row.Title: We have [ejaculation] and [female-ejaculation] - should they be one and the same?

row.Body:
The site is basically all about questions related to sex. Its like having a programming tag on Stack Overflow.

Only 3 questions have the tag right now, but should we remove it and discourage use in the future?
row.Title: Do we really need to have [sex]?

row.Body:
We just got a question (now deleted) asking about personal advice in a sexual relationship.

What is our stand on such questions? Do we accept them? If so, on what grounds, and what guidelines matter for the asking and asking of such questions?
row.Title: Relationship advice

row.Body:
Bad site, no cookie.

I wrote a nice little summary for the bdsm wiki. I got the notification that my edit was approved, but my writing isn't there! What happened to it? I really don't want to write all of that again...
row.Title: The site ate my tag wiki edit!

row.Body:
To what extent can questions related to ethics and sexuality be pertinent to this Stack Exchange? To what extent can answers be pertinent to the question and still allow the opinions of the author?

I figure that ethics play a big part in people's lives, not limited to sexuality. For many people, ethics deals with how people deal with each other in sexual relationships, which may involve consent or choice of birth control. A person who values the sanctity of life may choose a birth control method that does not violate that, perhaps asking about known contraceptives that are also abortifacients and avoiding the abortifacients in practice.
row.Title: Sexuality and ethics

row.Body:
Would it be useful to maintain, e.g. on meta.sexuality, a thesaurus (in the form, e.g., of a question with wiki answers) of english words concerning erotic aeras, various form of touch contacts, steps, protections, sexually transmitted diseases, ... ? This type of vocabulary is often not taught at school, hence often misunderstood by non-native english speakers on sexuality.SE.

[this question was first written in a comment]
row.Title: A sexuality-related english thesaurus, somewhere on meta.sexuality.SE: useful or not?

row.Body: I believe contraception and birth-control are completely synonymous for our purposes (or am I mistaken?) and ought to be merged.
row.Title: Merge tags: [contraception] and [birth-control]

row.Body:
Is this Stack Exchange limited to discussions on human sexuality as opposed to nonhuman sexualities?

Can we talk about the temporal isolation of two populations that may trigger speciation and macroevolution? Related, can we talk about the sexualities about our primitive hominid ancestors and their sexual culture?

What about questions of sexual intercourse between a human and his horse?
row.Title: Is nonhuman animal reproduction on-topic?

row.Body:
I might be able to answer this question, but my answer is entirely anecdotal. It's based on my personal experience as a woman with a sex drive and a menstrual cycle, as well as what I know from my close friendships with other women.

Is such an answer acceptable here? Or is scientific evidence required to backup such claims?
row.Title: Where does this site land on anecdotal/personal experience answers?

row.Body:
Although it has not happened so far, I foresee that graphic - either real or drawn - imagery will be included in questions and answers here. How should we handle these situations? Do we have a NSFW spoiler-box that we could use, or should we assume everyone visiting this sub-site is well aware of the possibility of pixels drawn on their screen?

Also - what about graphic pictures beyond work-safety, maybe of penile francture, for instance?
row.Title: Should/Can we include NSFW pictures in our questions and answers?

row.Body: The male masturbation question and the female masturbation question are pretty good questions. By the answers, I think many people assume "the present day". However, is it okay to present an outdated medical/scientific answer to a question? If it's not okay, then can such a thing still be included for historical insight? I know John Harvey Kellogg has a lot to say about masturbation, even though he is from the 19th century and his views are outdated!
row.Title: Is there a cut-off date to the time period?

row.Body:
Take this answer for example. I have downvoted the original revision because it lacked any links to official or semi-official resources, making it look like a personal opinion/knowledge.

After my comment, author added resourcs however they are not in English, so at least for me, useless.

What should we do in those situations? (both the author and the users viewing the answer)
row.Title: What should we do when we have resources in a non-English language?

row.Body:
I wrote this answer Is Nocturnal penile tumescence aka "morning wood" result of sexual arousal? and was downvoted because in my first version I failed to post links to my resources.

But all my resources are in German language (my native language), and this was the reason why I didn't post them.

Now I've posted the links, so that everybody who is able to read German texts can now proof that my answer is correct, but now I hear, that it might be a problem that I liked to non-english sites. (Two of them are medical sites, the third id German wikipedia)

So here are my questions:

  1. Is is mandatory, that you always post links to other sites when you give an answer?
  2. If you only have non-english resources, is it allowed to link to them?
row.Title: non-english resources

row.Body:
I have recently started experimenting with Tantric sex and would like to ask if it is okay to discuss this branch of sex on this site. In my opinion and based on whatever research I have carried out on Internet this seems to be a highly subjective topic especially due to the lack of definitive resources about this age old practice.

Are we ready to discuss this topic on sexuality.SE?
row.Title: Are questions about Tantric sex on-topic

row.Body: Is it possible for a man to have an orgasm without ejaculating? [duplicate] (jul 28) was marked as duplicate of Is it possible for a man to ejaculate without having an orgasm? (jul 29). This doesn't seem to make much sense to me; they're quite the opposite question unless one thinks that the proper, broader question is "Do ejaculation and orgasm always go together?" But, I think that they are each worthy of their own question; we can see in the answers different opinions and amounts of research on each question. Why were they marked as duplicate?
row.Title: Why was this question marked duplicate of a different, newer question?

row.Body:
On the Christianity.SE, I and other members greeted new members with preset greetings.

We would provide links about how to make good answers or questions, as well as welcoming newcomers to join and participate in the community.

Should we do that here?

How about this?

Welcome to the Sexuality.SE! Your response here looks constructive, informative, and pertinent. However, as this website has more of an academic bent, it is best to add some authoritative references to support your answer. Thank you for your cooperation.
row.Title: Adding a greeting to newcomers?

row.Body:
Take this first version of an answer for example. A user has downvoted this first version because it lacked any links to any resources.

First question:
Is this a good reason to downvote an answer because it contains no or not enough links to external resources?

Second (and more important) question:
Are Authors of answers forced to verify positions with links to external resources?
row.Title: Is posting links to resources mandatory?

row.Body:
I just saw a question about one individual's difficulties achieving orgasm in a particular set of circumstances.

I'm worried that such questions would end up with lots of duplication, and that we ought to try to find ways to make the questions more general, like, instead of (paraphrasing for effect) "I can't achieve orgasm, what can I do?", to have the question be "what things can someone keep in mind to help them achieve orgasm more easily?"... or some such thing.

There's a related question on meta about relationship advice, and the currently-best answer there is to avoid personal relationship advice. Additionally, there's a meta question about personal experiences being in answers, with the currently-best answer wanting reliable, verifiable information.

I'm wondering if we would also do well to extend such standards to the questions - to avoid questions seeking personal sexual advice, and try to keep the questions more general, and perhaps also more clinical. I do want to be able to answer questions about what kinds of things might get in the way of someone achieving orgasm, I just imagine it best to not have there be one canonical question about that (or perhaps several, differentiated in significant ways - e.g. one for men and one for women, say, or one about masturbation and one about intercourse, stuff like that).

Do folks agree? What standard shall we aim for on questions?
row.Title: Shall we try to de-personalize *questions*?

row.Body:
I was surprised to find that there are very few tags related to non-hetero sexual orientations. We really need to fix this. The following tags, or something like them, would seem to be a necessity:

  • Transgender
  • Cisgender
  • Homosexuality
  • Bisexuality
  • Asexuality
  • Queer
  • Lesbianism
  • Transsexualism/Transsexuality

There are other tags which might become necessary as the site grows, and although I am less certain about the specific tags here, the following might be a good idea, when the time comes:

  • Queer Theory
  • Pansexuality
  • Heteronormativity

And many more.

I don't have enough rep here to create tags, and even after I get more rep, I would only be able to create the tags by asking a question related to the tags. Since I'm hetero, I probably won't have much reason to ask such a question, so I think it might make sense to add the tags now, in part to show that we are open to all kinds of questions, orientations, and gender identities.

Am I off target here?
row.Title: Shouldn't we add these tags?

row.Body:
What I mean by "process of sexual intercourse" is the series of maneuvers and positions during sex.

Specifically, questions like the following:

  1. Why do men have to do the pelvic thrusting during sexual intercourse? Is it even necessary to complete sex?

  2. Why do women have to do female copulatory vocalizations? Is it even necessary to complete sex?

  3. How do men and women know when the sex act is over? What marks the end of a sex act? Is it the end of the human sexual response cycle or something else?

  4. Why don't men make any male copulatory vocalizations? Do the sounds even exist for males?

I am wondering whether it'd be on-topic to ask about the process of sexual intercourse, specifically concerning the physiology and behaviors.
row.Title: Can we ask any questions about the process of sexual intercourse?

row.Body:
I'm a little confused by the voting on a question I answered. There are now two answers to the question.

  • Both answers say more or less the same thing: "Sometimes a fetish is indicative of dysfunction, but in the vast majority of cases, it isn't."

  • The first answer refers to two Wikipedia pages. It contains one quote, a sentence long.

  • My answer refers to the DSM, which is the best source for information about psychological disorders, and explains how the DSM works, what it says about sexual fetishes, and what that means in common parlance. It includes a large number of quotations and references, and describes every fetish-related disorder recognized by the American Psychological Association. It explains how psychologists and psychiatrists identify a problem, what separates normal fetishes from disorders, and the criteria used to diagnose these disorders.

  • The first answer has 9 upvotes. My answer has two downvotes (actually, it has 3 downvotes and one upvote).

This isn't about my feelings being hurt, or my pride being wounded. I've been around long enough to know that you shouldn't take upvotes and downvotes personally. Frankly, I don't have a problem with a better answer beating my own answer - in fact, I see it as a chance to learn how to write better answers, and to learn from someone who is apparently better informed than I am.

But the flip side of being around long enough to take votes with a grain of salt is that I've also been around long enough to recognize the superior answer, whether it is mine or someone else's. In this case, my answer is clearly the better one, not because I wrote it, but because it is better referenced, more comprehensive, and strictly limited to hard facts rather than opinions.

I'm a bit concerned that despite our good intentions, some topics which are bound to come up on this site are so personal and intimate, and therefore are associated with such strong emotional feelings, that it is difficult to abide by the SE maxim that opinion-based answers are generally undesirable.

In other words, people have such strong feelings about their sexual lives that an objective answer which contradicts their preexisting beliefs is likely to come across as a personal insult. We don't like to hear our sexual activities called into question. It is extremely difficult to remain objective and avoid taking new information that goes against what we already believe as a personal attack.

This isn't a problem that will affect every question here: questions about sexual health, STDs, impotence, and medical issues are easily and objectively answerable. But when the question is something like "Is a fetish a sign of dysfunction?", and the answer is "Sometimes, yes, a fetish is a sign of dysfunction", it becomes very likely that people who have fetishes won't want to hear the correct answer. Why? Because it creates the unpleasant possibility that something you enjoy might not be healthy.

I might be wrong, but I think there is some truth to my line of reasoning. I don't know how we should handle this problem, or if it can even be handled. I didn't want to make a stink over nothing, so I brought the issue to the attention of some people on the SF&F SE. Every one of them, including at least one moderator, agreed with my assessment. I didn't solicit an evaluation of my answer versus the other answer, but I got such an evaluation anyway. Again, everyone agreed that mine was the better answer. I then mentioned my interpretation of the issue I described above, and yet again, everyone agreed that this was probably the problem.

On my primary SE site (Science Fiction and Fantasy), I am somewhat competitive, although I still prefer for the best answer to win, even if it isn't my own. I feel no such competitive urges here, because the subject matter is so much more important than Star Wars and The Lord of the Rings. People's health and emotional wellbeing are involved.

Therefore, on this site, I don't care about getting rep or badges. All that matters is providing people with the information they need to make informed decisions. The more comprehensive answer with the best sources should be the one that gets the most attention, because that answer is the one that is most likely to help the OP. If this situation is an indicator of what the future holds in store for the site, I think we should be a bit worried.

How do we deal with this? And is this site different from all the other SE sites? When the question is about personal sexual preferences, activities, and turn ons, do we value the most comforting answer, or the best referenced, most comprehensive answer? Is it possible to avoid bringing personal feelings into our voting in such cases?
row.Title: Are good answers the best cited and referenced ones, or simply the ones that we want to hear?

row.Body:
The tag [sexual-feelings] confused me at first. After reading the questions already tagged, it appeared to actually mean [arousal].

Should the tag be renamed?

A new [arousal] tag added, and [sexual-feelings] made a synonym?
row.Title: Should the [sexual-feelings] tag be renamed as [arousal]?

row.Body:
I must admit I wrankled a bit at this question. My reasons are several:

  • Lots of speculation/opinion (in the assumptions of the question itself, as well as the one answer written thus far);
  • It's talking about, if not promoting, a sexist misogyny sort of situation.
  • as far ad I can tell, there's either not really anything in a possible answer that would help someone with their contemporary sex life, or it could be asked in a way that leaves emperors entirely out of it.

So, on that third point especially:

Should we allow questions that are about historical figures? Or even about contemporary figures? Like, would a question about a modern celebrity scandal be on topic?

I'm kind of thinking this site should be about sexuality in relatively general ways. There could certainly be questions about specific things, but I think having it be about specific people is probably not deairable. Maybe that's even a better way to put this... I'd originally written the question as:

Are questions about historical figures' sex lives on topic?

Changed it. Another possible variation:

Should questions about particular people (contemporary or historical) be on topic?
row.Title: Are questions about specific people's sex lives on topic?

row.Body:
There is a question* I asked that received an answer that - for the most part - deviates off onto a tangent (one could even say 'rant' but lets not go there) that is unrelated to the question at hand.

I have raised this with the OP (who has since made some changes that have greatly raises the value of the answer), however there is still certain tangential information that is not needed, and as Snowman notes in the comment below, is very biased.

The great thing is it's not a bad answer - there's definitely good points in there: it's just that it's hard to see the relevant point through all the other, unrelated stuff around it.

Would it be wrong to attempt to cut down the answer to the relevant core point? Normally I wouldn't hesitate but as the question OP I feel this is probably overstepping my bounds a bit. What do you think?

* (Since there are so few questions in the beta so far, it'd be pretty hard to keep this ambiguous, so I'll just save you guessing and a few clicks: How does circumcision affect sex for the partner?)
row.Title: Would it be right to edit out parts of an answer if they are irrelevant to the point of the question?

row.Body:
Intercourse as a term is ambiguous - You and I are having an intercourse right now over the internet, for example.

Whilst I don't think the ambiguity will matter on this site much, the full/correct term for the sexual act is Sexual Intercourse. If we are to be as 'frank and clinical' about sex as possible, I believe we should avoid short-form/slang in our tags, and stick as close to the full terms as possible.

Thus, I propose we rename intercourse into sexual-intercourse

What do you think?
row.Title: Tag rename: [intercourse] -> [sexual-intercourse]

row.Body:
I asked two questions one each about the male and female sexual organs. I did not ask these because I didn't know about them, nor because I had a burning desire to know. I asked because these ARE simple questions that a surprisingly large number of people who are sexually active do NOT KNOW.

As such I thought having the question and answers here would be a valuable resource to the site. Answers to other similar questions could be routed to these answers. People looking for this answer might get directed here by having the question/answers come up in a google search. And saying 'You can easily google that' always seems like a cop out even if it's true.

I still think they would be valuable questions to have answered here on a site dedicated to their use. Both have been closed as too broad for a relatively simple question. I'm willing to try to narrow it down if any suggestions are made in how to do so. But I'm not going to bother trying if people will continue to want it closed.
row.Title: Questions about the human sex organs

row.Body:
So, 12 days into private beta, and according to the dry stats, all looking good.

However I have a feeling something is not right. The community (that is the group of active users) can't seem to decide what's on topic and what isn't on topic, also looks like we didn't really define what is going to be on topic to begin with, in enough details at least.

Can we please get some official statement as to where the site is standing? Good? Bad? Still waiting?
row.Title: Are we going to public beta?

row.Body:
I'm going to be a bit blunt:

This site is going to be more distracting and emotionally draining to maintain than your average subject. It is unfortunate; I suspect this is one of those areas we may actually be genuinely helpful, but the subject matter alone seems to demand that we support better separation of professional profiles from private. But even if the only concern was the topic, the site didn't exactly crush it in any meaningful way. For a subject with such broad and diverse appeal, we probably would have to close it on volume alone.

But I don't want to make this about the numbers.

Going into this, I was hoping for something that would go beyond the most common issues asked on every other site on the subject; perhaps something that leveraged the specific strengths of Stack Exchange to close that gap in what's out there. Even if the site were simply more popular, we could have a conversation about how to better integrate this into the network. Unfortunately, the site didn't attract that type of demand.

On the upside, this is the best attempt we've had at this subject yet. Many of these questions could be asked in the context of Health SE or even on Biology. But with the additional challenges facing this subject, the lower participation made these issues somewhat moot.
row.Title: Sexuality SE will be closing on Fri, 8/14

row.Body:
At this early point, Community Managers have that responsibility.

I've seen abby and Jon around, so we're in good hands. :)

I closed the question. Like I said in my comment there, I will happily step aside if the community overrules this decision, and I've asked some fellow community managers to have a look at the question and audit my decision as well.

However, I firmly believe the question is off-topic because this is - verbatim - a "Beta Q&A site for frank and clinical information on human sexuality." The question is not about human sexual behavior. Therefore, it is not on topic.

Additionally, I don't think animal sexuality should be on topic for a site like this. Again, that's up for discussion, but it's my stance that we cannot split our focus if we want to maintain any hope of a sustainable community growing here.

Age of consent, on its own, is off-topic in this site. Age and legality can be an important factor in relationships, and it would be important to consider in that context, but a question like "Is it legal if I X with Y-year old in the state of Z" would be clearly-off topic: Primarily legal or ethical advice belongs elsewhere.

Ultimately, it's probably going to depend on the question, and it can be hard to tell in advance, but generally I think the answer is no.

If the question concerns the law behind the age of consent, it's not really a question about human sexuality, but rather is a question about law.

If the question concerns the emotional and cognitive capacity to give consent, it's not really about human sexuality, but is about emotional/cognitive capacity.

I'm struggling to find a case where such a question is actually about human sexuality, rather than sexual law or cognitive consent. Both of these areas, I think, don't fall within the site's scope, but I'd be more than open to examples otherwise. There's probably something I'm not thinking of.

My first take is that this will be really difficult to answer until we have a few examples of questions that might actually be seen as a problem.

Let's be really careful about trying to anticipate a lot of "problems" before they actually happen. Trying to answer these type of what-if questions can lead to a lot of rule creation that will ultimately make this site all but unusable.

Devil's advocate here — If the question were phrased "Are humans unique in their enjoyment of voyerism?" … would that have worked here?

I don't have a strong preference either way, but the crux of the question does seem to be about the nature of human sexuality… even if it's asked in the context of learning how our activities compare to those found in the natural world. Certainly questions dealing primarily with sexual behaviors in animals are not on topic here. I'm just not sure this is the best example to drive home that premise.

No, I don't think we need such tags in the way you described.

Having male and female is enough, to make it clear what the question is about.

E.g. question tagged with both female and orgasm would clearly be about female orgasm only, and not about male orgasm. No need for female-orgasm for this.

Same way, if question is about both genders, no gender tag should be used.

No, tags are for categorization not for description.

On top of that, there is no point having male-female-female - where do we draw the line? There are 3 variations, all needing synonyms, and where do you stop? male-male-female-female, male-male-male-female-female? At some point, there won't be a tag for what someone wants, and they will be offended / confused / upset etc.

So we can have gender tags, although I'm not sure it's needed.

The question title should ask the question, not the tags. The tags are for me to find questions I want to answer (essentially). Would you ever want to focus on answering Male over Female questions. Possibly. So...

What system?

If we do, keep it to male and female. You could also have tags for threesome / group-sex and gay, lesbian, bi, queer etc (although this can also get into the minority excluded issue).

Why not female-to-female?

Essentially, this is getting very, very specific. Remember that the OP should be able to tag 85% of the time or more. Relying on front page editors isn't great - they system needs to be simple. Also, see above about descriptions.

You can change your display name on this site only by going to your profile on the main site and selecting "Edit Profile & Settings". When you are happy with your changes, select "Save changes just for this community". It will still be possible to connect your profile on this site to others on the network, but your name will not be directly associated with posts on this site. For people hoping to avoid Google associating their name with a particular sex act or whatnot, that should be sufficient.

If you don't want your account on this site associated with your accounts on other sites, you'll need to create a new user with separate credentials. Please see: How should sockpuppets be handled on Stack Exchange?

The question is not about human sexual behavior. Therefore, it is not on topic

The extent of the practice --voyeurism-- by humans more than justifies the legitimacy of the question.

A question about voyeurism which so far as we know is only practiced by humans has to belong in a site about human sexuality.

What are our alternatives? Wait for other non-human animals to create their own SE site so we can ask this question?

Certainly in the ongoing political/moral debates about what sexual behaviours are “natural” (as if that is relevant to morality), references to animal sexual behaviour are often made. Human sexual behaviour is very often judged in the context of non-human sexual behaviour: for the purpose of comparison.

That would be a good idea. I have a bachelor of science degree majoring in human physiology and pharmacology, so I know a lot about the physiology of sex, but I am not a doctor, so my answers should not be taken as medical advice, but there is the possibility that they might be taken so.

It is all too likely that questions on this site will have answers with medical implications.

We could have a disclaimer like:

Sexuality Stack Exchange is for educational purposes only and any discussion of health-related issues is not intended as a substitute for individualized diagnosis and treatment by a qualified healthcare provider.

If there's a flood of these questions then many people are struggling to find an answer. Right now they're all Googling their way into Yahoo answers... which is not helping them.

I think your example is actually a good question, on topic for the site, something many men/boys wonder about, and easy to construct a helpful answer for.

Duplicate questions that come in as would just be marked as such. I don't see an apocalypse coming.

Yes, we should always be striving to curate questions & answers into being more understandable: that's the reason why we allow community members to edit posts in the first place.

However, you should only edit when you see a problem. Don't go searching for one.

Another thing to note is that: should a question be completely mangled due to the translation and you can't make heads or tails of it yourself, do not hesitate to VTC as Unclear what you're asking. If the question is not understandable at all, the onus falls on the OP to make it readable, rather than us.
There is nothing NSFW in such a "banner":

I agree that we should avoid slang where possible but I also think we should watch out to not become too clinical.

Many users on this site are non-native English speakers and often have a very poor knowledge of clinical or scientific terms.

My suggestion would be using clinical terms where possible and if people ask or it is obvious that the asker will have troubles understanding the provided term we should also put the slang word.

Example:

Cunnilingus (eating her out)

Later in the post the word cunnilingus can be used without the slang word and the whole post will still be understandable.

I know that people are able to look words like this up but it would still help making post a lot more understandable.

I personally think this should be up to the asker or answerer since it is mostly personal word choice.

Where you would prefer Woman and Man, I prefer Female and Male since it sounds a lot more scientific and professional.

And because people have different preferences in word choice I think we should just leave it as it is.

Think of this (hypothetical) question:

What can a woman do, to increase the amount of semen that her partner ejaculates, or to increase the speed with which the ejaculate is emited?

I would tag it with female and ejaculation without meaning female-ejaculation. So, the combination {female, ejaculation} does not always mean {female-ejaculation}.

So maybe there should be an aditional tag male-ejaculation, but I think it should not replace ejaculation, because there might be questions that concern both forms of ejaculation, like

What are the physiological differences between female and male ejaculation? And what do they have in common?

Putting everything in a tag doesn't sound proper to me, its better to use combination of tags male, female and ejaculation.

Provide the details in title and body of question. Use tags for searching.

I disagree. I think that all words should be allowed, that are usual when friends at an after-work-beer in a bar are talking about those topics.

And I don't see a need to behave like nerdy headteachers.

I think it's ok to use clinical and scientific terms when talking about topics like anatomy of sexual organs or the »technical« functioning of those organs. But sexuality is much more then this. If sex was a matter of the functioning of the organs of reproduction, mankind would have become extinct millions of years ago, because sex is very exhausting and tiring, and nobody would have done it if it wasn't that fun that it is.

Sexuality is fun, it is lustfulness, yearning and desire, and this is what is in the words pussy, cock and fucking. Words like genitalia or intercourse are missing the urge and lechery, that is the most important part of Sex. Without the horniness and randiness that we all feel when we do it, we wouldn't do it.

So when we are talking about the feelings, the stimulation and the excitation that is what makes sexuality to what it is, then it should be allowed to use the words that everybody uses to describe this topics.

Some words about non-native-speakers

I'm a non-english-native-speaker (I speak German and live in Austria). (So please forgive all the english-errors I make here.) I can't share BrainStones point of view. When ever you learn English as a foreign language, you don't learn the slang words. No teacher tells his students what »eating out« or »giving head« means. When ever words in the field of sexuality are taught in school or in a course for adults, they are clinical and scientific terms. It's even hard to find words like »boner« or »to wank« in a english-to-foreign-language-dictionary. So when arguing with non-native-speakers, you end up with »use clinical terms«, not with »use slang«.

BUT:
When ever you english is good enough to be able to read and understand Questions and Answers on StackExchange, then you already have found a way to learn slang words and know most of them. (And if you don't know one of them, you have here the chance to learn it.) So in sum it is irrelevant if there are non-native-speakers around.

I agree. If there is going to be a guideline for users it should encourage neutral words. Slang makes reading questions painful, and often conveys meaning with much lower precision (like to fuck covering thousands of possible actions).

However, I fear that encouraging the use of formal / medical terminology is not the right way to go either. The detriment of medical words is that they are more difficult to use properly, and it will reduce the possible audience for answers on this site.

I would say that unless there is a specific reason to speak about body parts in anatomical terms no medical terms should be used. Use penis and not cock, yes, but don't overshoot and use prepuce instead of foreskin.

Other examples: coitus, cunnilingus, copulation, mating, fornication [also nowadays that could be slang], labia, etc.
No. It's not like programming is on StackOverflow. It's more like what jQuery is on StackOverflow. There is so much more to sexuality than sex that I feel the tag will prove useful in the future.

On the whole, particularly on Stack Exchange, I am wary of asking questions to be more general. More detail means better answers here, and that's what we want.

The more detail a question has, the more detailed an answer can be. However, it doesn't work in reverse. It's hard to give a detailed answer to a general question.

Someome who is asking a question may not realize that there's a significant difference between male/female/other anatomy concerning their question, and going with "partner" instead of providing detail limits how helpful an answer can be.

Instead, we should always encourage people to be as specific as possible, and then if the answer applies to all sexes we can close future questions as a duplicate. That way, if it warrants a specific answer, it can get one, while if it doesn't we can still use it as a duplicate target.

We should use tags as specifically as possible while still maintaining their usefulness as classification criteria.

In this case, I think male-ejaculation should be used in reference to males specifically, female-ejaculation w.r.t. females, and ejaculation only if the question is more general than both or neither apply.

It's useful to have as a catch-all, but should not be used where a better tag can be.

We should not use "compound" tags. That is to say,

  • female ejaculation

is not a substitute for

  • female-ejaculation

See this post on MSE for more on why that's a bad idea.

My personal feeling is that female- and male- ejaculation are distinct enough to warrant their own tags. Users of the English language apparently think so as well, since "female-ejaculation" is a term, and "ejaculation" is, as far as I'm aware, assumed to refer to males otherwise.

Thus I suggest female-ejaculation as a distinct tag, and then either ejaculation to refer specifically to male ejaculation or male-ejaculation for this purpose, possibly with ejaculation as an alias.

If there is a generic use-case for gender-non-specific ejaculation, we probably need a separate tag for that, because the assumption will generally be that ejaculation refers to men, and I foresee a long-term battle keeping that tag cleaned up.

I think sex is a bad tag, not because it doesn't mean something useful, but because its meaning is ambiguous.

  • "Sex" can refer to the act of sexual intercourse.
  • "Sex" can refer to gender.
  • "Sex" can refer to scantly-clad women in advertising.
  • "Sex" can refer to sexuality in general (as in "There's a new StackExchange site about sex")

I thus propose banning the sex tag, and instead using tags such as intercourse, gender, etc.

We ought to avoid these questions. Asking strangers on the Internet for intimate, personal advice about meaningful relationships is dangerous. We ought to close such questions, and refer the OP to seek advice from a personal friend, counselor, psychiatrist, clergy, etc.

Other sites have taken a similar approach.

  • http://meta.judaism.stackexchange.com/q/48/7227
  • http://meta.christianity.stackexchange.com/questions/255/pastoral-advice-questions
  • http://meta.health.stackexchange.com/q/56
  • Likely others

And it's even been brought up on Meta.SE: Wanted: A standard way for a site to have a prominent professional advice disclaimer

SE policy is that, given two questions, A, and B, if an answer to A answers B, then B is a duplicate of A.

This means that given these specific questions: "How can my girlfriend do X?", "How can my boyfriend do X?" and "How can my wife do X?", if the answer to the first one answers the other two, then the other two are duplicates, regardless of gender or the legal relationship between the partners.

Thus, in my opinion, there is nothing to be gained from policing posts to use the most generic, all-inclusive language possible. We're all adults here. We all know that sex is often enjoyed between people in situations other than our own, and that their experience may be relevant to our situation as well. If we can't handle that, should we really be asking questions about sex on the Internet in the first place?

And there is plenty to lose from such a policy of policing: It makes us look like politically-correct pedants. And it's likely to drive a lot of people away.

If you write a bad wiki excerpt, some one will reject it. This has the side effect of orphaning your wiki text. However, if someone gives it a good except, the wiki text will show up with the excerpt.

No, we shouldn't. Tags should describe the action itself, rather than the person, people, toys, etc performing said action.

Fellatio, Cunnilingus, Anal-insertion, etc are much more descriptive terms for the idea you wish to convey.

I think we have to very careful when handing out advice on sexual ethics. One person's ethical taboo is often embraced by another person. Some obvious examples are sex outside of/before marriage, consensual non-manogomy and homosexuality (heavily frowned upon by most modern religions, fully accepted by many other people). Some less-obvious examples might be related to what activities are appropriate with children:

  • Engaging in sex acts with what some cultures consider children (e.g. marriage and sex with a 12-year-old is acceptable in some cultures)
  • To what extent is talk about sex with children appropriate/ethical? Same goes for TV/movies, etc, or even parents being naked at home in front of their children

There's no clear-cut answer to what is or is not "ethical." Even the common litmus test of "between consenting adults" is difficult to define when we start considering that some cultures don't have a clear-cut definition of "adult."

Therefore, I suggest we generally stay way from questions asking for ethical judgement, and instead refer people to local laws, and relevant social or religious authorities.

By now the community has voted to reopen the question, and at this early stage, it sits as tied for second highest voted question.

I suppose this means the question is on topic.

I believe personal anecdotes are fine as long as you support them with some evidence in the literature. While sex is understandably a personal issue, sex, like many subjects, can be generalized and analyzed for patterns within the population. The only problem that I find with an answer made up of all opinions is that a different user may not be able to generalize to the greater population: the experience may be limited to only one person. Worse, that person may assume your experience as normal, while his own experience is not normal, even though there may be nothing statistically abnormal with his experience, and that you may be the abnormal one.

I think other Stack Exchange websites are no different either. Sources should be foremost; personal experiences embellish.

We should depend on reliable, verifiable information whenever possible. It's not bad to mention personal experience, but that should generally be tangential to the core of the answer. Links to studies, expert sex educators, etc, should be used generously for every answer, whenever possible.

I don't think we need to be as hard-lined about it as Skeptics.SE, for instance, which actively discourages links even to wikipedia as not authoritative enough. I also don't think we should make a hardline rule against anecdotes or personal experience, which Skeptics also does. But we should favor authoritative, verifiable sources.

There may be a few questions where a personal anecdote alone is a sufficient answer, but the only example I can think of at the moment would be a question along the lines of "Is there ever a risk of ____ during sex?" A personal anecdote in the positive ("Yes, once ___ happened to me during sex.") might be a sufficient answer.

1. Can we talk about the temporal isolation of two populations that may trigger speciation and macroevolution?

    No. This question is better on Biology.SE. (And side note: Certain aspects of human sexuality would be on-topic there, too, I'm sure)

  2. Can we talk about the sexualities about our primitive hominid ancestors and their sexual culture?

    I think this is a grey area. This is an active area of study (example). However, I believe this area of study generally belongs more in the arena of anthropology, but to my knowledge, there is no other suitable SE site to handle these questions. I also doubt we'll attract the types of experts who would be able to answer these questions.

  3. What about questions of sexual intercourse between a human and his horse?

    Yes, sigh, this is on-topic, I'm afraid. Hopefully we won't get many of these.

I think the degree of user expertise on this site is pretty much based on individual experience, and an answer speaking from yourself + friends is definitely useful. I do feel like adding the 'and friends' in there makes it a lot better right off the bat. If you can combine this with objective information, it's even better.

The answers will be judged by other 'experts', so if they definitely disagree and personal experiences don't combine, it can be downvoted for being wrong in that person's judgment.

Bottom line: while personal opinions and experiences aren't always the most reliable or accurate answers, they can make good answers by themselves, and great answers combined with objective information.

I don't think it should be one all-encompassing question - this requires a lot of maintenance and is essentially a disguised 'endless list' question, which generally don't work well in the Q&A format.

Instead, we should separate them out into a bunch of individual questions - one for each word, under a combined tag: terminology

So, for example, questions like

  • "What does 'STI/STD' stand for, and do they differ?"
  • "Is there a non-slang way of stating "doggy style?"

and so on, would be tagged with terminology. As always, on SE it's allowed (and encouraged!) To share you knowledge, so if you see a useful terminology question that hasn't been asked, you can ask and answer it yourself. This way, we can kick-start the thesaurus idea

To begin with, I would argue that viewing many SE sites is inappropriate for most work environments. Not because of the chance of content belonging to the unholy trinity of sex, politics, and religion, but because viewing the sites falls under "screwing around while on the clock." One good example is getting stuck in the time warp that is hot network questions.

That being said, I think it would be best to link to an off-site photograph with a warning that it is explicit per common community standards (e.g. the MPAA rating system would rate it R or NC-17).

Clinical diagrams of the type found in a textbook or physician's office should be acceptable to embed in a question or answer.

If a question does not specifically ask for historical insight, I would advocate for making such historical information acceptable as long as it is not the sole information in the question.

For example, a hypothetical question asks whether X is harmful to one's health. I believe it would be fine to say "we used to believe X was harmful a century ago, but since then medical study Y showed it to be safe for reason Z." As long as the end result is backing up the answer with current medical knowledge, that is fine.

In fact I would argue that including outdated medical information can be beneficial, if for no other reason than old information tends to live on as myths and old wives' tales. Including outdated information and showing how it is incorrect can benefit the larger audience that will eventually find these questions and answers through search engines.

I am told that people who study sexuality studies do treat contraception and birth control as distinctive things.

Link: https://womantowomancbe.wordpress.com/2008/01/24/birth-control-and-contraception-there-is-a-difference/

The actual, logical meaning of the term “contraception” is that it is a something that keeps conception from occurring. “Birth control” means that a birth does not take place, whether through contraception or abortion.

Link: http://www.differencebetween.net/science/health/difference-between-birth-control-and-contraception/

Birth control: Anything that helps control the birth of a child, according to the wishes of the parents, i.e. the planning to control the number of children born. This may include abortion.

Contraception: This word originates from the words contra + conception, i.e. anti-birth, or anything that prevents birth by natural or artificial means.

The sources above may not be sexuality studies academic journals, but they do support the view that birth control and contraception are not the same thing.

To be honest, I cannot articulate how they are different, because I do not study this field. All I know is that they are treated differently... at least, by the academics.

Colloquially, I think they are the same.

To make the subject more complex, some people believe that abortion is not considered "birth control". I think those people are using birth control and contraceptives synonymously, so when they say "birth control", they really mean "contraceptives", because abortion is, by the above definition, a form of birth control that can be triggered by abortifacients or medical equipment.
All kinds of sex are on-topic. If information is lacking, we may be unable to give high-quality answers, but that does not make the questions unworthy of being answered on this site.

Yes, of course.

Tantric sex is a form of sexuality, and this board is about sexuality. So tantric sex is on-topic (so also is BDSM, lesbian sex, cuddle sex, role plays or any other kind of sexual activity that you can think of).

ejaculate without orgasm

and

have an orgasm without ejaculating

are two different questions. They are similar and related, but non of them is a duplicate of the other. So I thinks both questions are legitime, and so I voted to reopen the question that is marked as duplicate.

I agree. I myself have a hard time understanding slang, including sexual slang. I usually do not use slang in my speech or writing in real life, so it feels unnatural for me to write or talk that way on this website. Using vulgar sexual vocabulary also sounds like I'm cursing, when I'm not.

Urban Dictionary is a life saver for me, because many definitions on that website are sexual. That website has taught me a lot of sexual jargon.

I would much prefer that everyone on this website stick with the formal, technical terms for anatomical parts and sexual behaviors.

Don't use "pussy". Use "vagina".

Don't use "cock". Use "penis".

Don't use "faggot". Use "homosexual person" or "gay" or "men-who-have-sex-with-men".

Communication is vital in a community. In order to be a community, we need to communicate. And peppering our speech with too many slang terms hinders us to communicate with each other.

I think it depends on the questions. Some questions can be depersonalized; some cannot. It really depends on the author's intention. What is the author's true intention for making the question? If other authors change the question to the extent that the original author's intention is changed, then it is best to make a new question, not revise that old question.

I do think a good question would be something like "What are the possible causes of sexual dysfunction in young men between the ages 18-25?" or "What is the most common cause of sexual dysfunction in young men between the ages 18-25?" Either of those questions may serve as a good substitute for the question you included about achieving orgasm. However, we don't know what the original author's intention is, and since my two questions are slightly different in focus, we may risk changing the author's intention if we were to use one of mine as a replacement for that author's words.

While I like the idea of using symbols in a banner, should we ever need one, it would be unacceptable to use the heteronormative male-female symbols exclusively. Better (i.e., more inclusive) options are available:

It has already become a problem. See my question. It seems clear that if an answer conflicts with personal beliefs and feelings, it is interpreted as an attack, and is therefore downvoted. This will be a very tricky problem. I don't know if there is any solution.

Tags do not exist until a question is asked that includes them.

Yes, the topic areas you list are (most likely) topic areas that we would cover, but unless (and until) there is a question that would deserve said tag, it will not exist.

Note: If a question is removed that is the only use of the tag, the tag will be deleted as well.

There shouldn't be any hard and fast rule about what quality of evidence is required for an answer; people can and already are judging whether evidence is sufficient with their votes, and the amount of evidence you need depends on the amount of support your claims need.

For example, in my highly upvoted How much masturbation is bad for males? answer, I cite wikipedia for uncontroversial descriptions of physical risks, I cite scientific papers for more controversial statements on mental risks and reference internet articles for areas where scientific study is lacking, and cite a sex advice column for a sexual risk that I don't expect has been studied scientifically. For broadly logical and agreeable statements, no citation at all should be necessary.

Providing harder and more scientific evidence improves an answer, and makes it more likely to be the best answer, but we shouldn't reject answers that depend of anecdotal experience for questions that aren't purely factual or that don't have sufficient scientific study.

The majority of downvoters1 to your answer have made it clear: Your answer was voted down not because it wasn't what they wanted to hear, but because it didn't answer the question clearly and concisely. It is my opinion that in your pursuit of "the perfect, totally complete answer," you have lost sight of the actual purpose of answers, which is to provide useful information (with citation where necessary) to the sorts of people asking the question you answer. Your elitist2 ideals for your answer simply don't work with the populist nature of the internet: the best answer is the one that is the most useful to the most people, not the most useful to the theoretical ideal reader that would like to learn as much as possible.

While popular opinions being voted over correct ones is a valid concern, at the moment it is an entirely theoretical one. I think that we should wait to see an example of the system not working properly before trying to fix a problem that might not appear in practice.

1: Spork and I (2 downvoters out of 3; I have since retracted my downvote but am still not upvoting because your tl;dr alone is not better than my answer and the rest of your answer is not very helpful to the average person in my opinion)

2: Elitism might be seen as an accusation but I think it's a clearly accurate description of your attitude. See also your stance that you would rather write a great book than a popular one, etc.

I think the benefit of using "male/female" is that the terms aren't age-specific. For most the first 2 decades of life, a male isn't a man, he's a boy; a female isn't a woman, she's a girl.

To each his/her own, of course, but male/female is more formal, more professional, and more broadly applicable.

I think it depends on the nature of the question, and the nature of the answer.

If the answer is giving specific factual type information, I'm inclined to suggest that we hold ourselves to, or close to, Wikipedia's Verifiability standard. In particular, the "challenged or likely to be challenged" standard for when to cite sources might be a good one. Which would make it OK to not bother finding sources for many things, yet if they're challenged, it's up to the original author (or any subsequent editor) to find such sources and present them to back up claims.

On the other hand, I think for questions that are fairly basic in nature, citing wikipedia itself is likely sufficient for an also-basic-in-nature answer, which may be all that is needed.

And if a statement is unlikely to be challenged ("HSV is very common", say), then in the absence of a challenge, it seems fair game to me to just state it.

Generally, though, I'm of the opinion that it's worth holding ourselves to a high standard for verifiability and accuracy. While this isn't an advice site, people are likely (I imagine, and perhaps hope) to make decisions about their sex lives based in part on answers they find here. As such, it's best if the answers they find are up to a high standard.

As such, to answer your specific questions, I would say yes, a downvote is potentially appropriate - provided it's accompanied by a comment that lets you know what you could do to change it. And see above for my wordier answer to the second question, but basically: not exactly, but sort of yes. [See above for longer version of this answer.]

That's my take. Perhaps others have different ones?

Thank you for asking this. I think it's good that we think about what sorts of answers we should most favor on the site.

I think a few things from the sex educator training I took may be useful here:

  1. The "PLISSIT model", and in particular the LI part - Limited Information. Your answer was 2,151 words long, to a question that was 37 words1. Frankly, my eyes glazed over. It was indeed "TL;DR" - I didn't vote, but neither did I read all of it. As someone prone to giving long-winded answers myself, I've come to realize that sometimes, that's not effective, even if everything you're saying is accurate, correct, and potentially useful to someone. They need a take-away. They need something they can digest. Take-away here: Your answer was too long, and not limited enough in its information. Even your TL;DR section was longer than the question by a factor of 41.
  2. "Positive-Neutral Tone" (also fitting in with the P in PLISSIT, which stands for Permission) - combined, these ideas basically say that you want to make it OK for someone to have asked their question (including, on this site, later people who stumble across it from their google searches), while generally giving neutral information. Taking an example from your answer, "It depends on what the fetish is, whether it causes problems in your life outside of your sexual relations, and a number of other factors." This perhaps takes the neutral too far; a suggested re-phrase, with a bit of positivity might be: "As long as fetishes aren't causing problems in one's life, they're probably healthy. When they start interfering with day-to-day life, that's when it might be classified as dysfunction." That's probably not perfect, especially for that question as-asked. The point I'm trying to make, though, is to give someone something that's just on the positive side of neutral, so they can feel OK about going forward from wherever they are now.

I could perhaps go on and on about this, but... To do so would counteract the point of my answer. I've probably already said to much.

Footnote (cited multiple times for the same note on purpose):

1 - not that's necessarily a bad thing, but it's probably a sign that there's a mismatch. If a question is specifically asking (even in a few words) for a detailed analysis of something, then this sort of discrepancy would make sense. But this question asked two essentially yes/no questions, prefaced with "Generally speaking". So in this case, it wasn't a fit.

Ultimately, I think this comes down to one thing:

Are you talking about gender or (biological) sex?

For gender, I would also prefer men/women (and perhaps boys/girls if/when talking about youth). If one is talking about biological sex, male and female may be more appropriate. Also, the latter words would be more appropriate when used as adjectives, e.g. if referring to testes as "male gonads" or ovaries as "female gonads" (for whatever reason, I'm aiming for a simple example).

Of course, all of this still resides within a binary construction of sex and gender, and for at least some questions, it would probably be good to be trans*-inclusive as well, by saying things like "many people with ovaries ...".

If you're speaking of an (adult) individual, whose gender is known (or has reason to be presumed in a hypothetical), I'd go with "man" or "woman", over "male" or "female". But when talking about, say, sexual response cycles (and making a distinction between sexes), I think it's more appropriate to say male or female.

So, I'd continue to edit in some cases, but be careful in how you do so. Hopefully the above serves as a good baseline for a guideline. Perhaps this can be expanded, too, as needed.

Yes, I believe it is fine to ask any question about the process of sexual intercourse. As this website is concerned with sexuality from an academic perspective, such questions (about coitus, diseases, birth control, gender, etc.) are on-topic on this website and can be provided with objective, evidence-based answers.

For example, this author discusses the mechanism of the pelvic thrust.

I would suggest that the tag should remain, as it could also be used for questions relating to a lack of sexual feeling. I second the idea of an arousal tag, and also the sexual attraction tag as mentioned in @saposhiente comment

No.

  • Someone else's sexual life is nobody's business.
  • Questions based on speculations don't make good questions.
  • If we can't separate the question about sexuality from the person and generalise it, I don't think it belongs here.

I can't think of questions where the person can't be removed to keep the question complete.
Even for non work environments, its better to avoid directly embedding the image in questions or answers. Its better to add a link with NSFW warning.

Yes

Of course you would expect me to say yes as I was the one who initially filed the question.

Here are specific rebuttals:

  • The question is not a speculation, as it is a documented fact that Chinese emperors ( usually) fathered numerous sons and daughters and they had thousands of concubines.
  • It's not promoting "a sexist misogyny sort of situation", unless you are willing to deem that historical curiosities are also sexism in nature ( because marriage norms in the past are sexism by today's standard). Also, why "sexist misogyny"-- if such a term can ever be applied to my question-- is not allowed on sexuality SE, when questions concerning other kind of "abnormal" sexual norms ( such as anal sex), are allowed? Isn't this double standard? Oh by the way, can a pro-family guy come along and ask the tag "homosexuality" be banned? After all, it doesn't conform to his sexual values.
  • "Emperors" here is a filtering criteria that makes the question more specific and answerable. If "emperors" are being left out of the question, then the question could be too general to be really answerable, as far as SE standards are concerned.

Now, as to the question of whether my question is answerable, and should it be answered here, on a SE site. The answer is a resounding YES! There could be studies done on the lifestyle and the food the emperors consumed that made them so...er... productive. I am not saying such studies are done, just that they can be done, by the historians who plowed through archaic files and literatures. Or maybe they are hidden in some parts of obscure Internet corners, that is not so easily accessible by even the mighty Google.

Sharing archaic knowledge--that is buried deep in the closed and dusty library environment or at some Internet corners--out in an open Internet forum, isn't this what SE is all about?

I think one needs to be careful with these types of questions, because on the one hand, they may be too personal, bordering on counseling, and on the other, they may be well documented in the corpus of historical literature. Historians must have researched into the sex life of King Henry VIII and how that has a direct impact on his political career.

I'd say that if someone has a sex life that is relevant to their other life choices, then it may be worth exploring. For example, I know that one of the Mongol emperors of the Yuan dynasty in China is claimed to have fathered many children through wives and rapes, and those children grow up to be part of the Chinese lineage. Since the man's sex life is relevant to the heritage of the Chinese people, I would think that his sex life would be germane for this website.

What we cannot do is offer something that a pastor, a rabbi, or a mental health counselor can offer: counseling advice.

It's always appropriate to edit questions and answers for clarity and brevity. That's the main reason SE has the wiki-like feature which allows us to do edits of other people's posts!

However, it's not always clear when some content is relevant, and in such cases, it's often wise to err on the side of caution, and leave a comment asking for clarity (which it sounds like you did).

Whether as the result of such a comment, or the OP has rolled-back your edit, if there is ever a dispute between the OP and an editor about the content of a post, we ought to defer to the OP's intent. If this makes the post low-quality, vote and flag accordingly.

I think keeping questions personal and specific is good because...

  • "What can one do when they don't achieve orgasm?" is too broad.

  • "What can a 24-year old male, with no girlfriend, who has sex once a month with an escort do to achieve orgasm?" just sounds awkwardly P.C. Lets not pretend that "I'm asking for a friend!" (unless you really are, I suppose).

Regardless of whether we use personal pronouns or impersonal ones, we need the same level of detail. And forcing everyone to use impersonal phrasing just sounds awkward for the sake of political correctness.

Lets allow OPs to ask however they are most comfortable.

And lets keep in mind that SE's definition of "duplicate question" really should perhaps be rephrased "duplicate answer." That is to say, if another question answer this question, it's a duplicate, even if the phrasing of the question makes them appear distinct.

So I don't think we're going to have an undue overflow of otherwise duplicate questions, simply because a 24-year-old and a 28-year-old both ask the same question.

One possible answer (I'm making strong "should" statements as a proposed possible stance, which we then may or may not adopt; I'm certainly open to considering other tactics, this is just one available proposal):

Yes, we should de-personalize questions.

This should be a site wherein information about sex and sexuality is made available. Non-judgemental, factual, free information.

This should not be a site where people come for sex advice generally, even if they may find information here that will help them guide their choices.

Many (most?) SE sites deal with non-English material from time to time, for a variety of reasons. What I offer comes largely from my observation of how this is handled on Skeptics.SE, where sometimes non-English material is the only reference option!

I think there are necessarily two parts to our response to non-English resources here:

  1. Non-English resources are better than no resources.

    If an OP is only able to offer non-English resources for whatever reason (only non-English studies have been done; They don't have a strong enough grasp on the English language to research English-language studies; whatever), we ought to accept them. Google translate makes it pretty easy to read most non-English material (within a very large margin of error--but still close enough for many purposes).

  2. When you come across a non-English resource from another poster...

    if you can find an English one to replace or supplement the original resource, please add it to the post!

    If you speak the language of the target material, and cannot find a replacement, you might even offer quoting and translating the most relevant bits into the question itself.

TLDR; We ought to allow non-English reference material, but at the same time work toward replacing it and/or supplementing it with translations and/or English equivalents.

Stack Exchange is, oddly enough, not designed to answer the question for the person asking it. That is simply a beneficial side effect.

The goal of Stack Exchange is to have a vast database of questions and answers for the Internet at large to search.

For this reason, a question should have only the necessary details to answer the question. Personal details such as "I have this problem" are superficial. Given the nature of this particular site I would recommend keeping questions as non-personal as possible.

There is a reason I do not use my real name and do not have my contact information in my Stack Exchange profile. When it was only Stack Overflow back in the day that was not much of a problem. Now I have my professional image (Stack Overflow, Super User, Programmers, The Workplace) mixed in with my personal image (Sexuality, Pets, Parenting). I follow a strict rule of not mixing my professional and personal lives unless absolutely necessary. Not everyone may agree with me or choose to do the same, but I drew that line.

In the interests of helping others who might not put that much thought into it, I would advocate for removing unnecessary personal information from questions and answers. Maybe not go on a crusade to edit every single post, however. But if I were going to edit a post anyway, it would be worth removing information not necessary to provide an answer. This has several benefits:

  • Makes the question more concise and easier to understand.
  • Weakens the link between the asker and the problem to be solved, making it less personal.
  • Makes the question more inviting to other people who might have a similar problem. I know if I see a highly specific problem statement that is close but not the same as my issue I am put off a little. If the question is more general (but still specific enough to be answerable) then it may apply to similar, related questions.

I see useful distinctions between all of these:

  • sexual-feelings
  • sexual-attraction
  • sexual-desire
  • sexual-arousal

They aren't synonyms, but the dividing lines are always going to be fuzzy, with considerable overlap. I think we just have to tolerate some fuzziness. This is not a subject that is going to let us be ultra-precise.

If we want to attract professionals in this field to participate here, we're going to need to tread a fine line between being overly-formal and being vulgar. Many sex educators and therapists wrestle with tone issues all the time, and most of them have a distinctive vocabulary that I would call "popular" - informal, not too scientific, but definitely not crude, and often accompanied by definitions or equivalent terms to encourage more accurate usage. For example:

Don't use "pussy". Use "vagina".

I would say:

Don't use "pussy". Use "vulva" or "vagina", depending on whether you are talking about the external or internal female genitals.

The problem with asking people to use clinical terms is that many of them will MISuse them. E.g., far too many people say "vagina" when they mean "vulva."

Don't use "cock". Use "penis".

I would say: Don't use "dick". Use "cock" or "penis".

"Dick" is pejorative, "cock" is merely informal. The goal should be clarity, not formality for its own sake.

Just because a word has a Latin origin doesn't mean it's automatically a good choice. For example, to my ear, "coitus, ... copulation, ... [and] fornication" all sound stilted and are inferior to "sex" or "intercourse." (Plus, "fornication" is an overtly biased, religious, and hostile term.)

And just because a word is slang, or a recent coinage, doesn't mean that it's the wrong choice either. For example, a recent question dealt with "vaginal farting," a term that a lot of people would object to. I supplied the correct term ("queefing") in my answer. It is certainly slang, but it is also the primary term used for the subject, and people need to know what it is called if they are going to search for further information.

The goal should be to communicate clearly without offending a normal person.
