We should certainly avoid terms with negative or pejorative meanings - cunt, faggot, asshole, dick, and any other term commonly used as an insult - but we also need to avoid being overly formal and using obscure words without defining them, because that creates a stilted sex-negative feeling and drives away many readers.

I think that on a site called Sexuality it's trivial that "intercourse" means sexual intercourse.

Don't think it should be renamed.

If there will be questions about other kinds of intercourse, they should be given specific tags of their own, possibly without the word intercourse to avoid confusion, e.g. interaction.

As the author of the "rant" in question, I would prefer to see downvotes over substantial edits that change the intent of the answer. Suggestions are always welcome, but it is very uncomfortable to have your name attached to something that has been altered in meaning.

Just to clarify what's going on, you asked a question that depends on opinions, and you - perhaps inadvertently - stepped into an intense ideological battle. The first answer given was a quote from a blatant example of dishonest science in support of one side. I was trying to describe some of the background of this debate and to explain why you aren't ever going to be able to get a simple, objective answer to your question. People are just too passionate about it, and at least one side is giving purely ideological answers. (That's all I've seen first hand, but it wouldn't surprise me if the other side is doing it too.)

If you asked a question about how women feel about having had an abortion, you would face similar problems about getting objective answers. If the question you ask is about people's subjective experiences, and the topic is sufficiently politicized, there's no way to get unbiased answers.

Not everything you see on the Internet is true. It's not enough to Google something and just paste the results into an answer. Sometimes you need to know the context in order to evaluate the source, and that's particularly true of highly controversial topics like circumcision and abortion.

IMHO, it's better to ban subjective questions about those two topics completely.

If your work doesn't directly involve questions of sexuality, just being on the web reading about sexuality is inappropriate and NSFW.

If we want to create a useful resource dealing with sexuality, we're going to have to allow appropriate images. Some questions can't be answered without them, at least not well, and using only off-site links defeats the purpose.

More to the point, if we want sex educators and researchers to come here and post questions and answers, a no-images policy is going to be a problem, because a lot of them are going to see that and go somewhere else. A no-images policy creates a prissy, puritanical tone that is inappropriate to the topic.

Ditto for closing questions like the one recently about the female genitals. If that's not relevant to sexuality, what is?

I vote for keeping it depersonalized. Otherwise this will degenerate into /r/sex or any other personal sex advice column/website. When the Beta ends, we'll get hundreds of individual variations a week on the same 10 or 15 questions (penis size, differential desire, PE, ED, anorgasmia, masturbation frequency, vaginal pain, etc., etc.).

It's better to have a general version of each of these questions, and at least one complete, authoritative answer to each one.

Really, that's what FAQ lists are for. And if someone really has a unique twist on a standard question, and demonstrates that they have read the FAQ answer(s) and the information there doesn't apply, then we can decide on a case-by-case basis whether it is something of interest to more than one person and should be allowed.

Two of your questions got closed as too broad - which is probably not a good reason, since they are extremely narrow. So narrow that the answer will be a single paragraph copy-pasted from Wikipedia. I think the circumcision one warrants its own post, but this answer will be for the reproductive system questions.

I think you might be wrong about many people landing here that want to know simple things like 'name all female sex organs'. Wikipedia does that just fine, and will be higher in the Google results (and rightly so).

I think, along with the close-voters, that the questions you posted are simply not covering enough ground. Aren't there any questions which you yourself don't already (fully) know the answer to? It may just be that those would be a great fit for this site!

A main tenet of the Stack Exchange network is that this site should "help make the Internet a better place." Filling our site with easy-to answer, bike-shed questions on every aspect of the topic of sexuality, which are already thoroughly and adequately answered elsewhere (such as wikipedia) does not make the Internet a better place.

From the help center (of ever Stack Exchange site):

You should only ask practical, answerable questions based on actual problems that you face.

You admitted above that these questions do not address problems you face.

They also show a lack of research effort (which, in my opinion is the real problem--not being "too broad" or even "too narrow").

If we one day we get a visitor who is having a problem identifying the parts of the reproductive systems, we will let them ask--and chances are such a question will be far more specific than the ones you came up with (I'm envisioning "What do you call this one particular part of the body?" types of questions).
The reason I voted to close those two questions is because they don't fit Q&A format. They make great topics for Wikipedia page or a blog, but there is no question in there.

This is seriously disappointing. I think Sexuality SE is a unique opportunity to create a fact and research-based resource in an Internet filled with misinformation about sex. I just put out a call to one of the top sex educators in the U.S., asking her to join us and to recruit other professionals to the beta. I don't know if they will respond to the call, but if they do, would you consider revisiting this decision?

It's surprising to me that the separation of professional profiles from private would come up as a reason - the most important reason even! How come sites like Christianity or Skeptics (or... any other .SE site) don't come under that scrutiny which clearly are not work related, and could be an issue for SO career recruiters? If I were a recruiter, alarm bells would definitely ring more loudly for this question on Hermeneutics, than for this one on Sexuality.

For me keeping up with questions on Skeptics is way more emotionally draining than it was for this site - and don't even get me started on the questions I run into from some other sub-sites. I honestly don't get that part - why is it somehow more draining to think of sexuality?

Volume was disappointing, but there were definitely good questions and well sourced answers in there. I would not cite the lack of Sex Educators as a concern, but more the lack of questions that would need the expertise of one. A success would be the question on effectiveness of birth control, or Is a hormonal IUD safe for females who may not be done developing physically/sexually?. I think many more of these would surface with a broader user base that explicitly does not require more educators, merely informed practitioners. Teaching children about sex is different from discussing issues with practitioners of it, and treating psychiatric issues is definitely not involved in the questions that were posed here.

With the reasons given here it seems like it was a project that was expected to fail - since the problem of separating professional from private was surely already seen in earlier iterations.

While I'm very sad to see this, I will say that I somehow think it's the right decision. I think if we had had a stronger core of some combination of sex educators and avid enthusiasts, this could have been made into something really strong and valuable... and there definitely was some valuable content created, here. There just needed to be more, and better.

I feel a bit guilty for not having done more myself to improve that. Honestly, though, I got a bit disheartened early on by some of the content that was getting created, that seemed to lack the kind of quality I would want from a stack exchange site. And while I did continue on and put some effort in after that, it was a lot less than it might have been.

And somehow, when I was trying to rally folks to come participate, during the commitment phase, I got much less traction than I'd been hoping for. Maybe people just didn't get the vision of what this could have been. Or maybe they imagined the problematic parts that I ended up seeing. I don't know.

What I do know is that I could imagine it being tried again, and that if the right crowd of folks were lined up for the initial private beta, I could imagine it really working.

Here's hoping we'll see that day, some day.

In the mean time, I'd like to express thanks to those who did put a bunch of time and energy into this - including into correcting or improving the content that I added. I got a few things wrong, and it got corrected - exactly the spirit of what this site should be... could be... Again, here's hoping we'll see that day.
